title: 115_s847
content: The Act is titled the "Women's Suffrage Centennial Commission Act" and includes sections on the establishment, duties, powers, personnel matters, and termination of the Women's Suffrage Centennial Commission. Authorization of appropriations is also addressed. The Sixty-Sixth United States Congress debated a women's suffrage amendment from 1919 to 1920. The House of Representatives approved the amendment on May 21, 1919, followed by the Senate on June 4. Tennessee became the 36th state to ratify the amendment on August 18, 1920, meeting the required support of three-fourths of states. The 19th Amendment to the Constitution of the United States was ratified after decades of advocacy for women's rights, allowing women to participate more fully in democracy. The centennial provides an opportunity to commemorate the women's suffrage movement and the changing role of women in civic life. The 19th Amendment was ratified in the United States after years of advocacy for women's rights, allowing women to participate fully in democracy. The centennial commemorates the women's suffrage movement and the evolving role of women in civic life. Establishment of Women's Suffrage Centennial Commission. The Women's Suffrage Centennial Commission is established with 14 members appointed by various officials, including the President, Speaker of the House, and Senate leaders. The Commission includes the Librarian of Congress and the Archivist of the United States. The Women's Suffrage Centennial Commission consists of 14 members appointed by officials like the President, Speaker of the House, and Senate leaders. The Commission includes individuals with expertise in relevant matters from various sectors, such as academia, government, and industry. The Women's Suffrage Centennial Commission aims for diverse representation in its members, appointed by key officials to ensure fair and equitable viewpoints on studied matters. The Women's Suffrage Centennial Commission members are appointed by key officials within 60 days of the Act's enactment. Vacancies are filled within 30 days. Meetings must be held within 30 days of all members being appointed. The Centennial Commission, once all members are appointed, will hold its first meeting. Subsequent meetings will be called by the Chair at least once every 6 months. A quorum of seven members is required, and the Commission will select a Chair and Vice Chair from its members. The Centennial Commission is responsible for carrying out specific duties. The Centennial Commission's duties include planning and executing programs to commemorate the 19th Amendment, encouraging participation from private organizations and governments, coordinating activities nationwide, serving as an information hub, and making recommendations to Congress. The Centennial Commission is tasked with developing recommendations for commemorating the centennial of the 19th Amendment. They are required to consult with the Historian of the Senate and the Historian of the House of Representatives when necessary. The Commission must submit periodic reports on their activities and plans to Congress and the President, as well as recommendations within 2 years of the enactment of the Act. The Centennial Commission will submit a report with recommendations for commemorating the 19th Amendment centennial to Congress and the President. The Centennial Commission has powers outlined in Section 5. The Centennial Commission has the authority to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and receive administrative support services as needed to fulfill its duties under the Act. Members and agents of the Commission can also take actions authorized by the Commission. The Centennial Commission can request administrative support services from the General Services Administration for its responsibilities. The Commission is authorized to procure supplies, services, and property, and enter into contracts, leases, or agreements, with a limitation on the duration of such agreements. The Centennial Commission is allowed to use the United States mails, solicit and manage gifts, bequests, and devises, award grants to States and the District of Columbia for commemorating the 19th Amendment. SEC. 6. CENTENNIAL COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Centennial Commission serve without compensation. They are allowed travel expenses and the Chair appoints an executive director and necessary personnel, with the authority to set their compensation. The Chair of the Centennial Commission is limited in setting compensation for appointed personnel. Federal employees can be detailed to assist the Commission, and temporary services can be procured as needed. The Centennial Commission can accept voluntary services as needed, despite restrictions on compensation for appointed personnel. The Centennial Commission will terminate either 30 days after completing activities honoring the 19th Amendment centennial or on April 15, 2021. The Federal Advisory Committee Act applies to the Commission's activities, with an exception for Section 14(a)(2). Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of appropriations is granted for fiscal years 2017 through 2021 to fund the activities of the Centennial Commission. Amounts allocated for each fiscal year will remain available until the Commission's termination.
